metadata.case_name: Yeshwant & Ors. v. State of Maharashtra
metadata.case_number: Criminal Appeals Nos. 175 of 1969 and 90 of 1970

facts.text: Sukal and Zingu, while returning from a fishing expedition, were waylaid and attacked by five persons at about 2.30 a.m. on 15-9-1966 at Marartola of Village Kati near an electric lamp post.
One assailant armed with an axe killed Sukal; another with a knife stabbed Zingu who escaped.
Eye-witnesses: Zingu (PW 8, injured), Babaji (PW 17), Jiwan (PW 18) who came from opposite direction.
Zingu extricated himself and fled crying for help, saw Babaji coming with lantern, rushed to Jainarain's house 200 feet away.
Dr. Narsing Galole (PW 2) attended Zingu after seeing Sukal unconscious; Zingu named Rupchand held him, Suraj assaulted him; Yashwant and Bhadya Master held Sukal, Tiwari attacked Sukal.
FIR lodged by Dr. Galole at 7.05 a.m. on 15-9-1966 named Suraj Koshti, Rupchand Koshti, Police Patil Yeshwantrao Turkar, Maharaj from Gondia; omitted Bhadia Master.
Chandanlal (PW 12, Sarpanch) heard Zingu say Yeshwant and Suraj held Sukal, Tiwari gave blows; Bhadya Master held him, Rupchand gave blows.
Dying declaration of Zingu at 7.30 a.m. before Taluka Magistrate: confused, named Mukadam Patel, Rupchand Patel, Bhadya Master, Suraj, guest from Gondia struck him.
Dr. Kale (PW 7) at Gondia Hospital examined Zingu at ~5.30 a.m., noted injuries, recorded Zingu said assaulted by somebody at 2-3 a.m., did not know names; later insertion of 'not' in record.
Sessions Judge Bhandara acquitted appellants; Bombay High Court (Nagpur Bench) allowed state appeal on 28/29 January 1969, convicted under 302/34 and 307/34 IPC.
Blood-stained clothes recovered from houses of Rupchand, Yeshwant, Bhadu (15-9-1966), Brahmanand (19-9-1966); only Yeshwant's dhoti had human blood group B, not matching victims.
Contusions on Bhadu and Rupchand approximating time of occurrence.
Brahmanand Tiwari: night watchman at Gondia, absent on night of 14-15 Sep 1966 per attendance register; had beard and adhesive tape on neck.
Identification parade for Brahmanand flawed: only 5 others, no similar bearded men, he had tape on neck, seen by witnesses before parade.

legal_issues.text: Reliability of eye-witness evidence of Zingu, Babaji, and Jiwan, particularly inconsistencies and Dr. Kale's evidence.
Identity of Brahmanand Tiwari as the axe-wielding assailant on Sukal.
Whether doubt as to one accused's identity entitles all to acquittal under Section 302/34 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Zingu gave inconsistent accounts; Dr. Kale's evidence that Zingu did not name assailants demolishes prosecution case.
Inconsistencies in dying declarations and statements; flawed identification of Brahmanand; village factions motivated false implication.
Doubt as to one accused (Brahmanand) requires acquittal of all under 302/34 IPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra; Jagir Singh v. State of Punjab

respondent_arguments.text: Eye-witnesses consistent; Dr. Kale's record altered deliberately; Babaji and Jiwan natural witnesses with better view.
Election defeat of Harlal (Yeshwant's brother) provides motive.

court_reasoning.text: Dr. Kale's evidence unreliable due to subsequent insertion in different ink; dying declaration shows Zingu's confused state but identified group.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dr. Kale's alteration deliberate, cannot knock bottom out of prosecution case.

court_reasoning.text: Babaji and Jiwan natural witnesses, close enough (25 steps), lantern light, corroborated by Zingu, Dr. Galole, Chandanlal; no motive for false implication.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Better position to observe than Zingu attacked from behind.

court_reasoning.text: Identity of Brahmanand doubtful: unknown previously, flawed ID parade, possible confusion with another bearded man.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Benefit of doubt to Brahmanand; evidence of identity of strangers deceptive.

court_reasoning.text: Doubt on one does not acquit others known to witnesses; Section 34 applies to remaining four who acted in common intention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Krishna Govind Patil depends on facts; here evidence sustains conviction of four.

holdings.text: Eye-witness evidence of Babaji, Jiwan, Zingu reliable and corroborated; convictions under 302/34 and 307/34 upheld for Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, Rupchand, Bhadu.
Identity of Brahmanand Tiwari not proved beyond doubt; acquitted.
Doubt as to identity of one participant does not necessitate acquittal of others under Section 34 IPC where common intention proved.

precedents_cited.case_name: Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Doubt on three accused did not allow conviction of fourth under 302/34 where evidence insufficient singly; not general principle.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagir Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 34 for cases where common intention but individual roles hard to prove; helps prosecution.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions under 302/34 for murder of Sukal; 307/34 for attempt on Zingu; Section 34 applies to common intention.

outcome.summary: Appeal of Brahmanand Tiwari allowed, acquitted and released; appeals of other four appellants dismissed, convictions and sentences under 302/34 IPC (life imprisonment for Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, Brahmanand originally but acquitted; wait no: Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, Brahmanand under 302/34; Rupchand, Bhadu under 307/34) maintained for Yeshwant, Suraj Lal, Rupchand, Bhadu.

key_quotes.text: "evidence as to identity, particularly of previously unknown persons, is a deceptive kind of evidence which has led to miscarriages of justice sometimes."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies giving benefit of doubt to Brahmanand.

key_quotes.text: "The benefit of this doubt can only go to the appellant Brahmanand Tiwari and not to the other accused persons who were known well to each eye witness."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes doubt on one from others.
